title: Mormon
description: An abridgment of the Book of Mormon, with an introduction abridged from Joseph Smith\mdash()History

verses.translation: I, Jo­seph Smith, write this his­to­ry to put all inquirers af­ter truth in pos­ses­sion of the facts.
There was in the place where I lived an un­u­su­al ex­cite­ment on the sub­ject of re­li­gion.

The cler­gy pro­mot­ed this scene of re­li­gious feel­ing in or­der to have eve­ry­bod­y con­vert­ed, let them join what sect they pleased. Yet when the converts be­gan to file off, some to one par­ty and some to an­oth­er, it was seen that the seemingly good feelings of both the priests and the converts were more pre­tend­ed than re­al, lost in a strife of words: priest contending a­gainst priest, and con­vert a­gainst con­vert.
I was at this time four­teen years old.

My mind was called up to se­ri­ous re­flec­tion and great un­eas­i­ness. My feelings were deep and of­ten poign­ant, but still I kept my­self a­loof from all the parties, though I attended their meetings as of­ten as oc­ca­sion would per­mit. So great were the con­fu­sion and strife a­mong the dif­fer­ent denominations, that it was im­pos­si­ble for a per­son as young as I was to come to any cer­tain con­clu­sion who was right and who was wrong.
In the midst of this war of words and tu­mult of opinions, I of­ten said to my­self, “What is to be done? If any of these parties is right, which is it, and how will I know it?”
One day I was read­ing James 1:5, which reads, “If any of you lacks wis­dom, let him ask God, who gives gen­er­ous­ly to all with­out re­proach, and it will be giv­en to him.”

This pas­sage entered with great force in­to eve­ry feel­ing of my heart. I reflected on it a­gain and a­gain, know­ing that if any per­son needed wis­dom from God, I did; for the dif­fer­ent sects un­der­stood the same passages of scrip­ture so dif­fer­ent­ly as to de­stroy all con­fi­dence in set­tling the ques­tion by an ap­peal to the Bible.
At length I came to the de­ter­mi­na­tion to “ask God.”
So, in ac­cord­ance with my de­ter­mi­na­tion, I re­tired to the woods to make the at­tempt. It was the first time in my life that I had made the at­tempt to pray vo­cal­ly.
Hav­ing looked a­round me, and find­ing my­self a­lone, I kneeled down and be­gan to of­fer up the desires of my heart to God. I had scarce­ly done so when
I saw a pil­lar of light o­ver my head.
When the light rested up­on me, I saw two personages. One of them said to me, “Jo­seph, this is my be­lov­ed son. Hear him.”
I asked the personages which of all the sects was right, and which I should join.
I was answered that I must join none of them.

A few days af­ter I had this vi­sion, I was with one of the preachers who was ver­y ac­tive in the re­li­gious ex­cite­ment. I gave him an ac­count of the vi­sion which I had had. He treated my com­mu­ni­ca­tion with con­tempt, say­ing that there were no such things as visions or revelations in these days.

I soon found that my sto­ry had ex­cit­ed a great deal of prej­u­dice a­gainst me a­mong the professors of re­li­gion. They ex­cit­ed the pub­lic mind a­gainst me and cre­at­ed a bit­ter per­se­cu­tion. This was com­mon a­mong all the sects,
and it of­ten caused me great sor­row.
How­ev­er, it was nev­er­the­less a fact that I had seen a vi­sion, and all the per­se­cu­tion un­der heav­en could not make it oth­er­wise.
I said in my heart, “Why per­se­cute me for tell­ing the truth? For I have seen a vi­sion. I know it, and I know that God knows it, and I can not de­ny it.”
I con­tin­ued to pur­sue my com­mon vocations in life, all the time be­ing

per­se­cut­ed by those who ought to have been my friends and to have treated me kind­ly. If they sup­posed me to be de­lud­ed, they ought to have endeavored to re­claim me in a prop­er and af­fec­tion­ate man­ner. I was left to mingling with all kinds of so­ci­e­ty, and fre­quent­ly fell in­to man­y fool­ish errors. In mak­ing this con­fes­sion, no one need sup­pose me guilt­y of any great sins, but I was guilt­y of lev­i­ty and some­times as­so­ci­at­ed with jo­vi­al com­pa­ny.

In con­se­quence of these things, I of­ten felt condemned for my weaknesses and imperfections. One eve­ning, I be­took my­self to pray­er and sup­pli­ca­tion to God for for­give­ness of my sins and follies.
While I was call­ing up­on God, I discovered a light appearing in my room, and im­me­di­ate­ly a per­son­age appeared.
He called me by name, said that he was a mes­sen­ger from God, and that his name was Moroni.
He said that there was a book, writ­ten up­on gold plates, giv­ing an ac­count of the form­er inhabitants of this con­ti­nent.
The vi­sion was opened to my mind so that I could see the place where the plates were deposited.
He added a cau­tion, tell­ing me that Satan would try to tempt me to get the plates for the purposes of get­ting rich. This he for­bade me, say­ing that I must on­ly get the plates to glo­ri­fy God.
The mes­sen­ger in­formed me that the time for bring­ing forth the plates would ar­rive in four years.
I went at the end of each year to the place where the plates were deposited. Each time I found the same mes­sen­ger there, and re­ceived in­struc­tion from him.
At length, the time ar­rived for obtaining the plates. Hav­ing gone as u­su­al at the end of an­oth­er year to the place where they were deposited, the same mes­sen­ger delivered them to me.
I com­menced to trans­late the Book of Mormon.
I, Nephi, am mak­ing a rec­ord of my proceedings dur­ing my life­time.
In the first year of the reign of Zed­e­ki­ah, king of Judah,
God showed my fa­ther, Lehi, man­y things a­bout the de­struc­tion of Je­ru­sa­lem. He went a­mong the peo­ple, and de­clared to them what he had seen.
When the peo­ple heard these things, they were an­gry with him, and sought his life.
God commanded my fa­ther in a dream to take his fam­i­ly, and de­part in­to the wil­der­ness.
He left his house, land, gold, sil­ver, and pre­cious things, and took noth­ing with him, ex­cept his fam­i­ly, provisions, and tents, and de­part­ed in­to the wil­der­ness.

La­man and Lem­uel, my old­er brothers, grumbled a­gainst their fa­ther be­cause he had led them out of Je­ru­sa­lem, leav­ing their land, gold, sil­ver, and pre­cious things. They said he had done this be­cause of the fool­ish imaginations of his heart.
They al­so did not be­lieve that Je­ru­sa­lem could be destroyed.
I be­lieved all that my fa­ther had spo­ken. There­fore, I did not reb­el a­gainst him like my brothers.
My fa­ther said to me,
“Laban has the rec­ord of the Jews, and it's en­graved on brass plates.
There­fore, God has commanded me that you and your brothers should re­turn to Je­ru­sa­lem, go to Laban's house, seek the records, and bring them here in­to the wil­der­ness.)
I said to my fa­ther, “I'll go and do what God has commanded, for I know that God gives no commandments un­less he prepares a way to ac­com­plish them.”
I said to my brothers, “It's wis­dom in God that we should ob­tain these records, that we may pre­serve for our chil­dren
the words spo­ken by all the ho­ly prophets.)
We went up to the house of Laban.
My brothers and I took the brass plates, de­part­ed in­to the wil­der­ness, and jour­neyed to our father's tent.
Af­ter we returned to our fa­ther, he was filled with joy, and al­so my moth­er was ver­y glad.
We had obtained the records which God had commanded us, and found that they had great val­ue to us, be­cause we could pre­serve the commandments of God for our chil­dren.
As we jour­neyed in the wil­der­ness, La­man and Lem­uel
were an­gry with me, and tried to take a­way my life,
but some of our com­pa­ny plead with them, and they stopped try­ing to take a­way my life.
I for­gave them all that they had done, and we trav­eled a­gain on our jour­ney.
If the chil­dren of men keep God's commandments, he provides means for them to ac­com­plish what he has commanded.
We came to the land which we called Boun­ti­ful, be­cause it had much fruit and wild hon­ey. God had pre­pared all these things that we might not per­ish.
We pitched our tents by the sea­shore, and re­joiced great­ly.
God said to me, Nephi,
“You shall con­struct a ship af­ter the man­ner that I will show you, that I may car­ry your peo­ple a­cross these waters.”
There­fore, I la­bored to keep the commandments of God.
When my brothers saw that I was a­bout to build a ship, they be­gan to grum­ble a­gainst me, say­ing, “Our broth­er is a fool, for he thinks that he can build a ship, and cross these great waters.”
I was deep­ly grieved be­cause of the hard­ness of their hearts. When they saw this they were glad, say­ing, “We knew that you could­n't con­struct a ship, and that you lacked judg­ment.
You're like our fa­ther, led a­way by the fool­ish imaginations of his heart. He has led us out of the land of Je­ru­sa­lem, and we've wandered in the wil­der­ness all these years.)
I, Nephi, of­ten went up on the moun­tain, and I of­ten prayed to God.
Af­ter I had fin­ished the ship, my brothers saw that it was good, and they humbled them­selves a­gain be­fore God.
We pre­pared man­y provisions, went in­to the ship with our wives and chil­dren,
and put forth in­to the sea.
Af­ter we had sailed for man­y days we ar­rived at the prom­ised land.
I made plates of o­re on which to en­grave the rec­ord of my peo­ple,
to keep the more sa­cred things for instructing my peo­ple.
The things which some men es­teem to be of great worth, both to the bod­y and soul, others set at naught.
The world, be­cause of their in­iq­ui­ty, will judge Jesus to be a thing of naught.
I have writ­ten these things that per­haps I might per­suade my peo­ple to re­mem­ber God.
For the time soon co­mes that all churches which are built up to make a prof­it, and to get pow­er, and to be­come pop­u­lar in the eyes of the world, must be brought low in the dust.
If you are o­be­di­ent to the commandments, and en­dure to the end, you will be saved at the last day.
Not man­y days af­ter Lehi's death, La­man and Lem­uel were an­gry with me,
so they sought to take a­way my life.
God warned me to de­part from them, and flee in­to the wil­der­ness a­long with all those who would go with me.

There­fore, I took my fam­i­ly, and Sam, my old­er broth­er, and Jacob and Jo­seph, my young­er brothers, and al­so my sisters, and their families. All those who went with me were those who be­lieved in the warnings and revelations of God.
We jour­neyed in the wil­der­ness for man­y days, and pitched our tents.
We were care­ful to keep the commandments of God in all things.
We prospered great­ly, for we sowed seed, reaped in a­bun­dance, and raised flocks, and herds, and animals of eve­ry kind.
I made man­y swords so that our enemies would not come up­on us and de­stroy us.
The words of Jacob, the broth­er of Nephi:
Woe to him who has all the commandments of God, and transgresses them, and wastes the days of his pro­ba­tion.

Oh the van­i­ty, and fool­ish­ness of men! When they are learn­ed they think they are wise, and they do not lis­ten to God's coun­sel, for they set it a­side, sup­pos­ing they know of them­selves, there­fore, their wis­dom is fool­ish­ness and it does not prof­it them.
But to be learn­ed is good if they lis­ten to God's counsels.
Woe to the rich, who des­pise the poor, and per­se­cute the meek, and whose hearts are on their treasures; there­fore, their treas­ure is their God.
Woe to the li­ar,
to the mur­der­er who kills de­lib­er­ate­ly,
and to those who com­mit for­ni­ca­tion.
Re­mem­ber, the mind set on the flesh is death, and the mind set on the spir­it is e­ter­nal life.
Turn a­way from your sins.
Pre­pare your souls for the day of judg­ment.
Do not spend mon­ey on what has no val­ue, nor your la­bor on what can­not sat­is­fy.
Cheer up your hearts, and re­mem­ber that you are free to act for your­selves: to choose the way of ev­er­last­ing death or the way of e­ter­nal life.
There­fore, rec­on­cile your­selves to the will of God, and not to the will of the flesh.
Jacob spoke man­y more things to my peo­ple, but I, Nephi, have on­ly writ­ten these.
We la­bor dil­i­gent­ly to write, to per­suade our chil­dren, and al­so our brothers, to be­lieve in Christ, and to be rec­on­ciled to God.
We talk of Christ, we re­joice in Christ, we preach of Christ, we proph­e­sy of Christ.
There are man­y churches built up which cause en­vy, strife, and mal­ice.
The dev­il leads them by the neck with a flax­en cord un­til he binds them with his strong cords for­ev­er.
God does not work in dark­ness.
Does he say to any­one, “De­part from me?” No.
Has he commanded any­one to de­part from the hous­es of wor­ship? No.
He commands that there shall be no priestcrafts, which are when men preach and set them­selves up as a light to the world, to make a prof­it, and get praise of the world.
God has for­bid­den this. There­fore, he has commanded that all men should have love, and ex­cept they have love they are noth­ing.
God has commanded men not to mur­der, lie, steal, en­vy, take his name in vain, have mal­ice, con­tend with one an­oth­er, or com­mit for­ni­ca­tion.
None of these iniquities come from God, for he does good a­mong the chil­dren of men.
One church will say to the oth­er, “Be­hold, I, I am God's.” And the oth­er churches will say, “I, I am God's.” Thus will eve­ry one say that has built up churches, and not to God.
They will con­tend with one an­oth­er, and their priests will con­tend with one an­oth­er.

Man­y will say, “Eat, drink, and be mer­ry, nev­er­the­less fear God. He will jus­ti­fy in com­mit­ting a lit­tle sin. Lie a lit­tle, take ad­van­tage of one be­cause of his words, dig a pit for your neigh­bor. There is no harm in this. Do all these things, for to­mor­row we die. If we are guilt­y, God will beat us with a few lashes, and at last we will be saved.”
Be­cause of pride their churches have be­come corrupted.
They rob the poor be­cause of their fi­ne sanc­tu­ar­ies, and their fi­ne cloth­ing. They per­se­cute the meek and the poor in heart, be­cause in their pride they have be­come ar­ro­gant.
Woe to those who turn a­side the just for noth­ing, and re­vile a­gainst what is good, and say that it has no worth!
Woe to him who says, “We have re­ceived the word of God, and we need no more of the word of God, for we have e­nough!”
God says, “To him who receives I will give more. From them who say, ‘We have e­nough,’ will be tak­en a­way what­ev­er they have.”
“Some will say, ‘We have a Bible, and there can­not be any more Bible.’
Be­cause you have a Bible you don't need to sup­pose that it contains all my words.
For I com­mand all men to write the words which I speak to them.)
There is noth­ing se­cret that will not be revealed.
Know that you must pray, for the evil spir­it teaches a man that he must not pray.
Lis­ten to these words and be­lieve in Christ, for they teach all men to do good.
Nephi gave me, Jacob, a com­mand­ment to write a few of the most pre­cious things.
The peo­ple be­gan to grow hard in their hearts, and to in­dulge some­what in wick­ed­ness,
there­fore I gave them these words:
Man­y of you have be­gun to search for gold, sil­ver, and pre­cious ores,

and prov­i­dence has smiled on you most pleas­ing­ly, that you have obtained man­y rich­es. Be­cause some of you have obtained more a­bun­dant­ly than others you are lifted up in the pride of your hearts be­cause of the cost­li­ness of your ap­par­el, and per­se­cute others be­cause you sup­pose that you are bet­ter than they.
Do you sup­pose that God justifies you in this thing? No, but he condemns you, and if you per­sist his judgments will speed­i­ly come to you.
Think of others like your­selves, be fa­mil­iar with all, and free with your possessions, that they may be rich like you.
But be­fore you seek for rich­es, seek for the king­dom of God.

Af­ter you have obtained a hope in Christ you will ob­tain rich­es, if you seek them, and you will seek them with the in­tent to do good: to clothe the na­ked, to feed the hun­gry, to lib­er­ate the cap­tive, and to ad­min­is­ter re­lief to the sick and the afflicted.
Don't you sup­pose that one be­ing is as pre­cious in God's sight as the oth­er?
You have bro­ken your ten­der wives' hearts, and lost your children's con­fi­dence, be­cause of your bad examples be­fore them. The sob­bing of their hearts ascends up to God a­gainst you.
Don't des­pise God's revelations.
Don't seek to coun­sel God, but to take coun­sel from him. For you know that he counsels in wis­dom, jus­tice, and great mer­cy.
Be wise; what more can I say?
Tak­en from chapters 11-23 of the Book of Mo­si­ah.
Zeniff con­ferred the king­dom on No­ah, one of his sons.
No­ah did not keep God's commandments, but followed the desires of his own heart.
He im­posed a tax of one fifth of all the peo­ple pos­sessed
to sup­port him­self, and his priests.
There was a man named A­bin­a­di who went a­mong the peo­ple say­ing, “God says, ‘Woe to this peo­ple, for I have seen their abominations, their wick­ed­ness, and their for­ni­ca­tion.
Un­less they re­pent they will be brought in­to bond­age.))
When king No­ah heard of Abinadi's words, he was an­gry. He said, “Who is A­bin­a­di that he should judge me and my peo­ple, or who is God to bring such great af­flic­tion on my peo­ple?
Bring A­bin­a­di here that I may kill him.)
They took him and car­ried him bound be­fore the king.
A­bin­a­di said to the priests, “Why do you set your hearts on rich­es? Why do you spend your strength with prostitutes?”
“You're an­gry with me be­cause I've told you the truth.
But fear and trem­ble be­fore God, for he redeems none who have wil­ful­ly rebelled a­gainst him, who have known his commandments, and re­fused to keep them.)
The king commanded the priests to take A­bin­a­di and cause him to be put to death.
There was a young man a­mong the priests whose name was Al­ma, and he be­lieved Abinadi's words, there­fore he be­gan to plead with the king to let A­bin­a­di de­part in peace.
But the king was more an­gry and sent his servants af­ter Al­ma to kill him.
But he fled from them and hid. Be­ing concealed for man­y days, he wrote all the words which A­bin­a­di had spo­ken.
The king said, “A­bin­a­di,
you will be put to death un­less you take back all the evil you've spo­ken a­bout me and my peo­ple.)
A­bin­a­di said to him, “I will not take back what I've spo­ken to you, for it is true.
It will stand as a tes­ti­mo­ny a­gainst you at the last day.)
King No­ah was a­bout to re­lease him, for he feared that God's judgments would come up­on him.
But the priests said, “He has re­viled the king.” There­fore the king was in­cit­ed to an­ger a­gainst him, and delivered him to be killed.
A­bin­a­di suffered death by fire be­cause he would not de­ny the commandments of God, hav­ing sealed the truth of his words with his death.
Al­ma, who had fled from king Noah's servants, be­gan to teach Abinadi's words.
Man­y be­lieved his words.
These things were done in the borders of the land, that the king might not know.
But they were made known to the king.
He said that Al­ma was in­cit­ing the peo­ple to re­bel­lion a­gainst him, there­fore he sent his ar­my to de­stroy them.
Now Al­ma, hav­ing been warned by God, told his peo­ple, there­fore they gathered to­geth­er their flocks, and their grain, and
they fled eight days' jour­ney in­to the wil­der­ness.
They came to a beau­ti­ful and pleas­ant land,
and be­gan to till the ground, and build buildings. They were in­dus­tri­ous, and worked ver­y hard.
The peo­ple wanted Al­ma to be their king, for his peo­ple loved him.
But he said to them, “It's not ex­pe­di­ent for us to have a king.
Re­mem­ber the in­iq­ui­ty of king No­ah and his priests.
King No­ah oppressed you, and you were in bond­age to him and his priests.
Be­cause you have been delivered out of the hands of king No­ah and his peo­ple, I ask you not to trust any man to be a king o­ver you.)
Thus did Al­ma teach his peo­ple that eve­ry man should love his neigh­bor as him­self, and that there should be no con­ten­tion a­mong them.
King Ben­ja­min had three sons, and he caused them to be taught so that they might be­come men of un­der­stand­ing.
He al­so taught them a­bout the records which were en­graved on the brass plates, say­ing: “My sons,

it was­n't pos­si­ble for our fa­ther, Lehi, to re­mem­ber all these things; but he could read these engravings, and teach them to his chil­dren, that they could teach them to their chil­dren, e­ven down to the pres­ent time.)
King Ben­ja­min grew old, and saw that he must ver­y soon go the way of all the earth.
There­fore, he
proclaimed to all the peo­ple to gath­er them­selves to­geth­er to hear his words.
When they ar­rived, they pitched their tents on eve­ry side, eve­ry fam­i­ly be­ing sep­a­rate from one an­oth­er.
He caused his words to be writ­ten and sent to those who could not hear him, that they might al­so re­ceive his words.
These are the words which he spoke:
I have not commanded you to come here to fear me, or to think that I am more than a mor­tal man.

But I am like you, sub­ject to all kinds of infirmities in bod­y and mind; yet the peo­ple have cho­sen me, and God has al­lowed me to be a king; to serve you with all the might, mind and strength which he has grant­ed me.
I have been al­lowed to spend my days in your serv­ice, and have not sought gold, or sil­ver, or any kind of rich­es from you.
Nei­ther have I al­lowed you to be con­fined in dungeons, or to make slaves of one an­oth­er, or to mur­der, or steal, or com­mit a­dul­ter­y.
And e­ven I, my­self, have la­bored with my own hands that I might serve you, and that you should not be bur­dened with taxes.
Yet, I have not done this to boast.
I tell you so you may learn wis­dom; that you may learn that when you serve your fel­low beings you are on­ly serv­ing God.
If I, whom you call your king, la­bor to serve you, then should­n't you la­bor to serve one an­oth­er?
If I, whom you call your king, mer­it any thanks from you, O how you should thank your heav­en­ly king!

Con­sid­er the bless­ed and hap­py state of those who keep God's commandments. They are bless­ed in all things, both tem­po­ral and spir­it­u­al, and if they re­main faith­ful to the end they are re­ceived in­to heav­en to dwell with God in never-ending hap­pi­ness.

The nat­u­ral man is an en­e­my to God, and will be for­ev­er, un­less he puts off the nat­u­ral man and becomes like a child: sub­mis­sive, meek, hum­ble, pa­tient, full of love, will­ing to sub­mit to all things, e­ven as a child submits to his fa­ther.
Be­lieve in God. Be­lieve that he is, and that he cre­at­ed all things. Be­lieve that he has all wis­dom. Be­lieve that man does not com­pre­hend all that God can com­pre­hend.

Be­lieve that you must re­pent of your sins and for­sake them, and hum­ble your­selves be­fore God. Ask in sin­cer­i­ty of heart that he would for­give you. And now, if you be­lieve all these things see that you do them.
Hum­ble your­selves, call­ing on God dai­ly.
If you do this you will al­ways re­joice,
and you will not have a mind to in­jure one an­oth­er, but to live at peace, and to re­pay eve­ry man what he is due.
You will not al­low your chil­dren to go hun­gry, or na­ked, or to trans­gress God's laws and fight and quar­rel with one an­oth­er.
But you will teach them to walk in the ways of so­ber truth, to love one an­oth­er, and to serve one an­oth­er.
You will help those who need your help. You will give of your possessions to him who stands in need. You won't al­low the beg­gar to pe­ti­tion you in vain, and turn him a­way to per­ish.
Per­haps you will say, “The man has brought his mis­er­y on him­self, there­fore I won't give him of my food, or of my possessions, for his punishments are just.”
Who­ev­er does this has great cause to re­pent. Un­less he repents he perishes for­ev­er, and has no part in the king­dom of God.
For aren't we all beggars? Don't we all de­pend on God for all our possessions, for food and cloth­ing, for gold and sil­ver, and for all our rich­es of eve­ry kind?

If you judge the man who petitions you for your possessions, that he per­ish not, and con­demn him, how much more just will be your con­dem­na­tion for with­hold­ing your possessions, which don't be­long to you but to God.
Woe to that man, for his possessions will per­ish with him. I speak to those who are rich in the things of this world.

I say to the poor, you who on­ly have e­nough to re­main from day to day; I mean all you who de­ny the beg­gar, be­cause you have not. Say in your hearts: “I don't give be­cause I don't have, but if I had I would give.”
If you say this in your hearts you re­main guilt­less. Oth­er­wise you are condemned, for you cov­et what you have not re­ceived.

To re­tain for­give­ness of your sins: Share your possessions with the poor, eve­ry man ac­cord­ing to what he has, such as feed­ing the hun­gry, cloth­ing the na­ked, visiting the sick and help­ing them, both spiritually and tem­po­ral­ly, ac­cord­ing to their needs.

And see that all this is done in wis­dom and or­der; for it is not nec­es­sar­y for a man to run faster than he has strength. It is ex­pe­di­ent for him to be dil­i­gent, that he might win the prize. There­fore, all things must be done in or­der.
Re­mem­ber that who­ev­er borrows from his neigh­bor should re­turn the thing, as he has a­greed, or else you will sin; and per­haps you will cause your neigh­bor to sin al­so.
If you do not watch your­selves, and your thoughts, and your words, and your deeds, and ob­serve God's commandments, e­ven un­til the end of your lives, you must per­ish.
How does a man know the mas­ter whom he has not served, and who is a strang­er to him, and is far from the thoughts and intents of his heart?
Mo­si­ah be­gan to reign in his father's place.
He gathered all the peo­ple to­geth­er, and
read the records of Zeniff to them.
He al­so read the ac­count of Al­ma and his peo­ple.
Al­ma al­so spoke to them, preaching re­pent­ance and faith on God.
King Mo­si­ah had no one to con­fer the king­dom on, for none of his sons would ac­cept the king­dom.
There­fore he took the records
and con­ferred them on Al­ma, who was the son of Al­ma, and commanded him to keep and pre­serve them, and al­so to keep a rec­ord of the peo­ple, handing them down from one gen­er­a­tion to the next.
King Mo­si­ah wrote to the peo­ple say­ing,
“You want to have a king.
He to whom the king­dom right­ly belongs has de­clined.
If I ap­point an­oth­er in his place, I fear there would a­rise contentions which would cause wars, which would de­stroy the souls of man­y peo­ple.)
“Let us be wise and an­tic­i­pate these things, and do what will make for peace.

There­fore I will be your king for the rest of my life. Nev­er­the­less, let us ap­point judges, to judge this peo­ple ac­cord­ing to our law, and we will new­ly ar­range the af­fairs of this peo­ple.)
“Be­cause all men are not just, it is not ex­pe­di­ent to have a king or kings to rule o­ver you.
For be­hold, how much in­iq­ui­ty does one wick­ed king cause to be com­mit­ted, and what great de­struc­tion!)
“You can on­ly de­throne an in­iq­ui­tous king through much con­ten­tion, and blood­shed.

For he has his friends in in­iq­ui­ty, and he keeps his guards a­round him, and he tears up the laws of those who have reigned in right­eous­ness be­fore him, and he tramples God's commandments un­der his feet,
and he enacts laws ac­cord­ing to his own wick­ed­ness, and who­ev­er does not o­bey his laws he causes to be destroyed.)
“There­fore, choose judges by the voice of the peo­ple, that you may be judged ac­cord­ing to the laws which have been giv­en by our fathers.
Ob­serve this and make it your law: do your busi­ness by the voice of the peo­ple.)
The peo­ple were con­vinced of the truth of his words,
there­fore they relinquished their de­sire for a king.

The peo­ple loved Mo­si­ah, for they did not con­sid­er him a ty­rant who was seek­ing for that mon­ey which corrupts the soul, for he had not exacted rich­es from them, nei­ther had he de­light­ed in shed­ding blood, but he had established peace in the land, and had grant­ed to his peo­ple that they should be delivered from all kinds of bond­age, there­fore they esteemed him be­yond meas­ure.
They ap­point­ed judges to judge them ac­cord­ing to the law.
Al­ma was ap­point­ed to be the first chief judge.
Thus ended the reign of the kings o­ver the peo­ple.
In the first year of Alma's reign in the judg­ment seat, there was a man named Nehor
who was preaching that eve­ry priest and teach­er should be­come pop­u­lar, and should not la­bor with his hands, but be supported by the peo­ple.
As he was preaching, Nehor be­gan to con­tend sharp­ly with a man
named Gid­e­on.
Nehor drew his sword and killed Gid­e­on.
Nehor was brought be­fore Al­ma to be judged.
Al­ma said to him,
“You are condemned to die, ac­cord­ing to the law.”
He suffered a shame­ful death,
yet this did not stop priest­craft from spreading through the land, for there were man­y who loved the vain things of the world.
There was a strict law a­mong the peo­ple of the church that no one should per­se­cute those who did not be­long to the church.
They imparted of their possessions to the poor, and the needy, and the sick, and the afflicted. They did not wear ex­pen­sive cloth­ing, yet they were neat and come­ly.
Be­cause of the stead­i­ness of the church they be­came ver­y rich, hav­ing an a­bun­dance of eve­ry­thing they needed.
In their pros­per­ous circumstances, they did not send a­way any who were na­ked, or hun­gry, or sick. They did not set their hearts on rich­es, there­fore they were gen­er­ous to all.

The peo­ple of the church be­gan to grow proud be­cause of the great rich­es they had obtained by their dil­i­gence. They were lifted up in their pride, for they be­gan to wear ver­y ex­pen­sive cloth­ing.
Now this caused Al­ma much af­flic­tion.
There be­gan to be great contentions a­mong the peo­ple of the church. There was en­vy, strife, mal­ice, per­se­cu­tion, and pride.
Al­ma, see­ing the afflictions, persecutions, and in­e­qual­i­ty, be­gan to be ver­y sorrowful.
He selected a wise man, and
delivered the judg­ment seat to him.
He did this that he him­self might go out a­mong his peo­ple to re­mind them of their du­ty, and to tear down all the pride, craft­i­ness, and con­ten­tion a­mong them.
And thus, Al­ma delivered up the judg­ment seat, and con­fined him­self whol­ly to the priest­hood of God.
This is what Al­ma said to the peo­ple of the church:
I ask you, have you ex­pe­ri­enced a might­y change in your hearts?
Do you look for­ward and view this mor­tal bod­y raised in im­mor­tal­i­ty to stand be­fore God to be judged ac­cord­ing to the deeds which have been done in the mor­tal bod­y?
Do you im­ag­ine that you can lie to God in that day, and say, “God, our works have been right­eous,” and that he will save you?
If you have ex­pe­ri­enced a change of heart, can you feel so now?
Have you walked, keep­ing your­selves blame­less be­fore God? Could you say, if you were called to die at this time, that you have been sufficiently hum­ble?
Are you strip­ped of pride? If not, you are not pre­pared to meet God.
Is there one a­mong you who mocks his broth­er, or heaps persecutions on him?
Woe to such a one, for he is not pre­pared, and must re­pent!
All of you who de­sire to fol­low the voice of the good shep­herd, come out from the wick­ed, be sep­a­rate, and don't tou­ch their un­clean things.
If I had­n't giv­en the judg­ment seat to an­oth­er, to reign in my place, I could not have come at this time.
Lay a­side eve­ry sin which so eas­i­ly entangles you, which binds you down to de­struc­tion. Show God that you are will­ing to re­pent of your sins.

Be hum­ble, sub­mis­sive and gen­tle; o­pen to rea­son; full of pa­tience and long-suffering; ex­er­cis­ing self-control in all things; dil­i­gent in keep­ing the commandments of God at all times; asking for what­ev­er you need, both spir­it­u­al and tem­po­ral; al­ways thanking God for what­ev­er you re­ceive.
Al­ma came to a cit­y called Am­mon­i­hah.
As he entered the cit­y he said to a man, “Will you give a hum­ble serv­ant of God some­thing to eat?”
The man was named Am­u­lek, and he brought bread and meat and placed them be­fore Al­ma.
Al­ma stayed with Am­u­lek for man­y days be­fore he be­gan to preach to the peo­ple.
Al­ma and Am­u­lek went out a­mong the peo­ple, to de­clare God's words.
Al­ma be­gan to ex­plain things to them say­ing, “God on­ly imparts to the chil­dren of men ac­cord­ing to the at­ten­tion and dil­i­gence which they give him.
There­fore, he who hardens his heart receives the less­er por­tion of the word, and he who will not hard­en his heart receives the greater por­tion of the word.)
“All men must die, and be brought be­fore God to be judged ac­cord­ing to our works.
For our words, our works, and our thoughts will con­demn us.)
“We see that death co­mes to man­kind. Nev­er­the­less there was a space grant­ed to man in which he might re­pent; there­fore this life be­came a probationary state; a time to pre­pare to meet God.
Be­cause we know these things, let us re­pent, and not hard­en our hearts.)
“I wish, from the in­ner­most part of my heart, that you would lis­ten to my words, and cast off your sins, and not pro­cras­ti­nate the day of your re­pent­ance,

but that you would hum­ble your­selves be­fore God, and watch and pray con­tin­u­al­ly, that you may not be tempted a­bove what you can bear, be­com­ing hum­ble, meek, sub­mis­sive, pa­tient, full of love and all long-suffering;
hav­ing faith in God; hav­ing hope that you will re­ceive e­ter­nal life; al­ways hav­ing the love of God in your hearts.)
Al­ma spoke man­y more words to the peo­ple which are not writ­ten in this book.
Af­ter he had spo­ken to the peo­ple, man­y of them be­lieved his words, and be­gan to re­pent, and to search the scriptures.
Am­u­lek had left all his gold, sil­ver, and pre­cious things, be­ing rejected by those who were once his friends and al­so by his fa­ther and his relatives.
Al­ma, see­ing all these things, took Am­u­lek to his own house, and ministered to him in his tribulations.
I, Al­ma, would de­clare re­pent­ance to eve­ry­one, that they should re­pent and come to God, that there might be less sor­row on the earth.
But I sin in my wish, for I should be con­tent with what God has al­lot­ted me.
For God grants to all nations, of their own na­tion and lan­guage, peo­ple to teach what he sees fit that they should have.
A man be­gan to preach a­gainst the com­ing of Christ.
Now there was no law a­gainst a man's be­lief.
If a man de­sired to serve God, it was his priv­i­lege, but if he did not be­lieve in him there was no law to pun­ish him.
This man, named Kor­i­hor, preach+ed say­ing,
“These things which you call prophecies are fool­ish traditions of your fathers.
You can't know of things you don't see.

You say that you see a re­mis­sion of your sins, but it is the ef­fect of a fren­zied mind. This de­range­ment of your minds co­mes be­cause of the traditions of your fathers, which lead you a­way to be­lieve in things which are not so.)
And he told them that what­ev­er a man did was no crime.
He re­viled a­gainst Al­ma and the priests, ac­cus­ing them of lead­ing a­way the peo­ple af­ter the sil­ly traditions of their fathers, to glut on the labors of the peo­ple.
Al­ma said to him, “You know that we don't glut our­selves on the labors of this peo­ple. I've la­bored with my own hands for my sup­port.
Not­with­stand­ing the man­y labors I've performed in the church, I've nev­er re­ceived as much as one pen­ny for my la­bor; nei­ther have any of my brothers.)
Al­ma re­ceived news that one Zoram was lead­ing the peo­ple to bow down to idols.

As preaching the word had a great ten­den­cy to lead the peo­ple to do what was just --- it had had a more pow­er­ful ef­fect on the minds of the peo­ple than the sword, or any­thing else which had happened to them --- there­fore Al­ma thought it was ex­pe­di­ent to try the pow­er of the word of God.
There­fore he went a­mong the Zoramites to preach the word to them.
Af­ter much la­bor, they be­gan to have suc­cess a­mong the poor, for they were cast out of the synagogues be­cause of their coarse cloth­ing.
One of them said, “They cast us out of our synagogues and we have no place to wor­ship God. What shall we do?”
Al­ma said to them,
“Do you sup­pose that you can on­ly wor­ship God in your synagogues?
Do you sup­pose that you must on­ly wor­ship God once per week?)
“God is mer­ci­ful to all who be­lieve his word.
He imparts his word to men, and wom­en. This is not all, lit­tle chil­dren of­ten have words giv­en to them which con­found the wise and the learn­ed.)
“We will com­pare the word to a seed. If you make room to plant a seed in your heart, you will be­gin to say with­in your­selves, ‘It's a good seed, for it begins to en­light­en my un­der­stand­ing.’
Be­cause you have tried the ex­per­i­ment, and planted the seed,
you know that the word has sprouted up, that your un­der­stand­ing begins to be enlightened, and your mind begins to ex­pand.)
As the tree begins to grow, you will say: “Let's nour­ish it care­ful­ly, that it may bear fruit.
But if you ne­glect the tree, and don't think a­bout its nour­ish­ment, it with­ers a­way.
Now, this is­n't be­cause the seed was not good, or be­cause its fruit would not be de­sir­a­ble, but it's be­cause you won't nour­ish the tree.)
“You've said that you could­n't wor­ship God be­cause you're cast out of your synagogues, but you're great­ly mis­tak­en.
Do you re­mem­ber what Zenos, the proph­et of old, said a­bout pray­er?
He said, “You are mer­ci­ful, O God, for you have heard my pray­er, e­ven when I was in the wil­der­ness,
and when I cried to you in my field.
And a­gain, when I turned to my house, you heard my pray­er.
You are mer­ci­ful to your chil­dren when they cry to you, to be heard by you and not by men, and you will hear them.))
Af­ter Al­ma had spo­ken, Am­u­lek taught them, say­ing,
“Cry to God when you're in your fields, o­ver all your flocks.
Cry to him in your hous­es, o­ver all your house­hold, both morn­ing, mid­day, and eve­ning.
Cry to him o­ver the crops of your fields, that you may pros­per in them.
Cry o­ver the flocks of your fields, that they may in­crease.
You must pour out your souls in your se­cret places, and in your wil­der­ness.
Don't sup­pose that this is all; if you turn a­way the needy, and the na­ked, and don't vis­it the sick and afflicted, your pray­er is emp­ty, and brings you noth­ing, and you are hypocrites.)
“This life is the time for men to la­bor.
Don't pro­cras­ti­nate the day of your re­pent­ance.
Have pa­tience, and bear all kinds of af­flic­tion. Don't re­vile a­gainst those who cast you out be­cause of your great pov­er­ty, lest you be­come sinners like them.)
Al­ma gathered his sons to­geth­er:
My son Helaman, take the records which have been entrusted to me,
and keep a rec­ord of this peo­ple.
You may sup­pose that this is fool­ish­ness, but by small and sim­ple things are great things brought to pass.
These things have en­larged the mem­o­ry of this peo­ple, and con­vinced man­y of the er­ror of their ways.
In your youth, learn wis­dom and to keep the commandments of God.
Be so­ber. My son, fare­well.
My son Shiblon,
be dil­i­gent and tem­per­ate in all things.
Don't be lifted up in pride. Don't boast in your own wis­dom, or in your much strength.
Use bold­ness, but not overbearance. Bri­dle all your passions, that you may be filled with love. Re­frain from i­dle­ness.
Don't say, “God, I thank you that we are bet­ter than our brothers.” Rath­er say, “God, for­give my unworthiness, and re­mem­ber my brothers in mer­cy.”
Be so­ber. My son, fare­well.
My son Corianton,
this is what I have a­gainst you: you went on boasting in your strength and your wis­dom,
and you went af­ter a pros­ti­tute.
Don't you know that these things are an a­bom­i­na­tion to God?
Re­pent and for­sake your sins, and don't go af­ter the lusts of your eyes any­more.
Don't al­low your­self to be led a­way by any vain or fool­ish thing.
Don't seek af­ter rich­es or the vain things of this world, for you can­not car­ry them with you.
Be mer­ci­ful to your brothers. Deal just­ly, judge right­eous­ly, and do good con­tin­u­al­ly.
For what you send out will re­turn to you a­gain.
Who­ev­er will come may par­take of the waters of life free­ly, and who­ev­er will not come is not com­pelled to come.
My son, de­clare the word with truth and so­ber­ness.
In the fifty-third year of the reign of the judges, Nephi, the son of Helaman, the son of Helaman, be­gan to reign in the judg­ment seat.
In the sixty-second year of the reign of the judges,
Nephi delivered the judg­ment seat to Cezoram,
for Nephi was wea­ry be­cause of the in­iq­ui­ty of the peo­ple. He gave up the judg­ment seat to preach the word of God for the rest of his life, and his broth­er Lehi al­so.
For they remembered what their fa­ther Helaman had said to them:
“My sons, de­clare these words to the peo­ple:

Re­mem­ber that it is up­on the rock of Christ that you must build your founda­tion; that when the dev­il sends forth his might­y winds, when all his hail and his might­y storm beats up­on you, it will have no pow­er to dra­g you down to the gulf of mis­er­y and end­less woe, be­cause of the rock on which you are built.)
In the sixty-sixth year of the reign of the judges, Cezoram was murdered. His son, who had been ap­point­ed by the peo­ple in his place, was al­so murdered.
The peo­ple grew ver­y wick­ed.

For God had bless­ed them so long with the rich­es of the world that they be­gan to set their hearts on their rich­es. They be­gan to seek for prof­it that they might be lifted up one a­bove an­oth­er. There­fore they be­gan to mur­der, rob, and plun­der, to get mon­ey.
Those murderers and plunderers were a band formed by Gadianton.
They had signs, and se­cret words to rec­og­nize a broth­er who had entered in­to the cov­e­nant, that what­ev­er wick­ed­ness he did he should not be in­jured by those who belonged to his band.
Thus they might mur­der, plun­der, steal, and com­mit for­ni­ca­tion and all kinds of wick­ed­ness, con­tra­ry to the laws of their coun­try and the laws of God.
Nephi saw the peo­ple in a state of aw­ful wick­ed­ness, and the Gadianton robbers fill­ing the judg­ment seats, hav­ing usurped the au­thor­i­ty of the land;
let­ting the guilt­y go un­pun­ished be­cause of their mon­ey; be­ing held in of­fice to get mon­ey and glo­ry of the world, that they might more eas­i­ly com­mit a­dul­ter­y, steal, and kill.
This great in­iq­ui­ty had come up­on the peo­ple in on­ly a few years.
Nephi said to the peo­ple,
“How could you have for­got­ten God?
Be­hold, it is to get mon­ey, and to be praised of men.
Woe will come to you be­cause of that pride which you have al­lowed to en­ter your hearts, which has lifted you up be­cause of your ver­y great rich­es!)

“You have rejected the truth, and rebelled a­gainst God. In­stead of stor­ing up for your­selves treasures in heav­en, where noth­ing destroys, you are ac­cu­mu­lat­ing for your­selves an­ger for the day of judg­ment.”
They would not lis­ten to his words.
Thus we can see the unsteadiness of the hearts of the chil­dren of men.

At the ver­y time when God prospers his peo­ple, do­ing all things for their wel­fare and hap­pi­ness, then is the time that they hard­en their hearts, and for­get God, be­cause of their ease, and ver­y great pros­per­i­ty.
How fool­ish, vain, and quick to do in­iq­ui­ty, and how slow to do good, are the chil­dren of men. How quick to set their hearts on the vain things of the world!
How quick to be lifted up in pride; how quick to boast; and how slow to re­mem­ber God, and to lis­ten to his guid­ance. How slow to walk in wisdom's paths!
They ne­glect God's guid­ance, and will not have him as their guide.
Bless­ed are they who will re­pent and lis­ten to the voice of God.
There was one Samuel who came in­to the land, and preached re­pent­ance to the peo­ple.
They would not let him en­ter the cit­y, so he got on the cit­y wall, and
said to them:
God says, “Be­cause of the hard­ness of the hearts of the peo­ple, un­less they re­pent I will take a­way my word from them.
Your enemies, of the fourth gen­er­a­tion, will live to see your ut­ter de­struc­tion.)
Your rich­es are curs­ed be­cause you have set your hearts on them, and have not listened to the words of him who gave them to you.

You don't re­mem­ber God in the things with which he has bless­ed you, but you al­ways re­mem­ber your rich­es, not to thank God for them. Your hearts swell with great pride, un­to boasting, en­vy, strife, mal­ice, per­se­cu­tion, mur­der, and all man­ner of in­iq­ui­ty.
Woe to you, be­cause you drive out the prophets, and mock them, and throw stones at them, and kill them, just as they did long a­go.
And now you say, “If we had lived in the time of our fathers, we would not have killed the prophets. We would not have stoned them, and driv­en them out.”

You are worse than they. If a proph­et co­mes to you and declares your sins and iniquities, you are an­gry with him, and look for ways to de­stroy him. You will say that he is a false proph­et, be­cause he testifies that your deeds are evil.
But if a man co­mes to you and says, “Do this and there is no in­iq­ui­ty. Walk af­ter the pride of your eyes, and do what­ev­er your heart desires,” you will say that he is a proph­et.
You will dress him in ex­pen­sive cloth­ing be­cause he speaks flattering words, and says that all is well.
Re­mem­ber that you are free. You are permitted to act for your­selves. God
has al­lowed you to know good from evil, and to choose life or death. You can do good and have good re­stored to you, or you can do evil and have evil re­stored to you.
Man­y heard the words of Samuel, and be­lieved him, and confessed their sins.
But those who did not be­lieve Samuel were an­gry with him. They threw stones and shot ar­rows at him as he stood on the wall, but they could not hit him.
He jumped down from the wall, fled out of their land,
and was nev­er heard from a­gain.
The peo­ple still remained in wick­ed­ness.
The Gadianton robbers had be­come so nu­mer­ous, and killed so man­y of the peo­ple, that all the peo­ple
were com­pelled, for the safe­ty of their lives and their wom­en and their chil­dren, to take up arms a­gainst those Gadianton robbers to main­tain their lib­er­ty.
The peo­ple be­gan a­gain to pros­per, and there was great or­der in the land.
There was noth­ing to hind­er the peo­ple from prospering con­tin­u­al­ly, ex­cept if they fell in­to trans­gres­sion.
There be­gan to be some disputes a­mong the peo­ple, and some were lifted up in pride and boasting be­cause of their ver­y great rich­es, e­ven to great persecutions.

The peo­ple be­gan to be dis­tin­guished by rank, ac­cord­ing to their rich­es and their chances for learn­ing. Some were ig­no­rant be­cause of their pov­er­ty, and others re­ceived great learn­ing be­cause of their rich­es.
And thus there a­rose a great in­e­qual­i­ty in the land, so the church be­gan to be bro­ken up.
Now the cause of the in­iq­ui­ty was this: the peo­ple were puffing up with pride, seek­ing for pow­er, au­thor­i­ty, rich­es, and the vain things of the world.
They did not sin ig­no­rant­ly, be­cause God's will had been taught to them, there­fore they wil­ful­ly rebelled a­gainst God.

The peo­ple di­vid­ed in­to tribes, eve­ry man ac­cord­ing to his fam­i­ly. They had come to an a­gree­ment that they would not go to war with one an­oth­er, or tres­pass a­gainst one an­oth­er, so in some de­gree they had peace in the land. Nev­er­the­less, their hearts were turned from God, and they stoned the prophets and cast them out.
Nephi preached man­y things to the peo­ple.
They were an­gry with him.
On­ly a few were con­vert­ed to God.
A great mul­ti­tude were gathered to­geth­er
talking a­bout Jesus Christ.
While they were talking with one an­oth­er, they heard a voice as if it came from heav­en.
They looked up, and saw a man descending out of heav­en. He came down and stood a­mong them.
He reached out his hand and spoke to the peo­ple, say­ing,
“I am Jesus Christ, whom the prophets tes­ti­fied would come in­to the world.”
When Jesus said these words the whole mul­ti­tude fell to the ground, for they remembered that it had been prophesied that Christ would show him­self to them.
Jesus commanded Nephi to come for­ward,
and called others, and said to them,
“There shall be no disputes a­mong you, as there have been un­til now.
For he that has the spir­it of con­ten­tion is not of me, but is of the dev­il, who is the fa­ther of con­ten­tion, and he stirs up the hearts of men to con­tend with an­ger, one with an­oth­er.)
When Jesus had spo­ken these words to Nephi, and those who had been called, he said to the mul­ti­tude:
Bless­ed are the poor in spir­it who come to me, for the king­dom of heav­en is theirs.
Bless­ed are all those who mourn, for they will be comforted.
Bless­ed are the meek, for they will in­her­it the earth.
Bless­ed are all those who hun­ger and thirst for right­eous­ness, for they will be filled with the ho­ly spir­it.
Bless­ed are the mer­ci­ful, for they will re­ceive mer­cy.
Bless­ed are all the pure in heart, for they will see God.
Bless­ed are all the peacemakers, for they will be called sons of God.
Bless­ed are all those who are per­se­cut­ed be­cause of my name, for the king­dom of heav­en is theirs.
Bless­ed are you when peo­ple in­sult you and per­se­cute you, and false­ly say all kinds of evil a­gainst you be­cause of me,
for you will have great joy and be glad, for your re­ward in heav­en will be great; for in the same way they per­se­cut­ed the prophets who were be­fore you.
Do peo­ple light a lamp and put it un­der a bas­ket? No, but on a stand, and it gives light to eve­ry­one in the house.
There­fore let your light shine be­fore this peo­ple, so that they may see your good works and glo­ri­fy God who is in heav­en.
You have the commandments.
Un­less you keep my commandments, you will nev­er en­ter in­to the king­dom of heav­en.
It is writ­ten that you shall not mur­der, and who­ev­er murders will be sub­ject to God's judg­ment.
But I tell you that eve­ry­one who is an­gry with his broth­er will be sub­ject to his judg­ment. And who­ev­er says, “You fool,” will be sub­ject to hell fire.
There­fore, if you want to come to me, and re­mem­ber that your broth­er has some­thing a­gainst you,
go to your broth­er, and first be rec­on­ciled to him, and then come to me with full pur­pose of heart, and I will re­ceive you.
It is writ­ten that you shall not com­mit a­dul­ter­y.
But I tell you that eve­ry­one who looks at a wom­an with lust for her has al­read­y com­mit­ted a­dul­ter­y in his heart.
Al­low none of these things to en­ter your heart,
for it is bet­ter to de­ny your­selves these things than to be thrown in­to hell.
It is writ­ten that you shall not break your oath, but shall ful­fill your oaths to God.
But I tell you, make no oath at all,
but let your state­ment be “Yes” or “No”. Any­thing more than this is evil.
It is writ­ten, an eye for an eye, and a tooth for a tooth.
But I tell you, don't re­sist an evil per­son. In­stead, if some­one slaps you on the right cheek, turn to him the oth­er al­so.
If some­one wants to sue you and take your shirt, let him have your coat al­so.
If some­one forces you to go one mile, go with him two.
Give to him who asks you, and don't turn a­way from him who wants to bor­row from you.
It is writ­ten, “Love your neigh­bor and hate your en­e­my.”
But I tell you, love your enemies, bless those who curse you, do good to those who hate you, and pray for those who mis­treat you and per­se­cute you
that you may be sons of God. For he makes his sun rise on the evil and the good.
You should give to the poor, but be­ware of prac­tic­ing your right­eous­ness be­fore men to be seen by them.
So when you give to the poor, don't sound a trum­pet be­fore you, as the hypocrites do, to be praised by men. They have their re­ward.
But when you give to the poor, don't let your left hand know what your right hand is do­ing,
so that your giv­ing may be in se­cret.
When you pray, don't do as the hypocrites, for they love to pray to be seen by men. They have their re­ward.
But when you pray, go in­to your room, shut your door, and pray to God who is in se­cret.
When you pray, don't use mean­ing­less rep­e­ti­tion like the pagans, for they think that they will be heard for their man­y words.
When you fast, don't look gloom­y like the hypocrites, for they dis­fig­ure their faces to show men that they are fasting. They have their re­ward.
But when you fast, a­noint your head, and wash your face,
so that your fasting is not ob­vi­ous to men, but to God, who is in se­cret.
Don't store up for your­selves treasures on earth, where moth and rust de­stroy, and thieves break in and steal.
But store up for your­selves treasures in heav­en, where nei­ther moth nor rust destroys, and where thieves do not break in and steal.
For where your treas­ure is, there your heart will be al­so.
No one can serve two masters; for ei­ther he will hate the one and love the oth­er, or he will be de­vot­ed to the one and des­pise the oth­er. You can­not serve God and mon­ey.
Don't judge, so that you won't be judged.
For in the way you judge, you will be judged; and with the meas­ure you use, it will be meas­ured to you.
Why do you look at the speck in your brother's eye, but don't no­tice the log in your own eye?
There­fore, what­ev­er you want others to do to you, do al­so to them.
Be­ware of false prophets who come to you in sheep's cloth­ing, but in­ward­ly are rav­en­ous wolves.
You will rec­og­nize them by their fruits. Are grapes gathered from thornbushes, or figs from thistles?
Like­wise, eve­ry good tree bears good fruit, but a bad tree bears bad fruit.
A good tree can­not bear bad fruit, nor can a bad tree bear good fruit.
So you'll rec­og­nize them by their fruits.
Eve­ry­one who hears these words of mine and acts on them will be like a wise man who built his house on the rock.
The rain fell, the floods came, and the winds blew and beat a­gainst that house. Yet it did not fall, be­cause its founda­tion was on the rock.
Eve­ry­one who hears these words of mine and does­n't act on them, will be like a fool­ish man who built his house on the sand.
The rain fell, the floods came, and the winds blew and beat a­gainst that house, and it fell.
Turn to me, and en­dure to the end, and you will live. For to him who endures to the end, I will give e­ter­nal life.
I've giv­en you the commandments, there­fore keep my commandments.
I can see that you're weak, that you can­not un­der­stand all that I'm speak­ing to you.
There­fore, go to your homes, and pon­der on the things which I've said, and ask God that you may un­der­stand.
You must watch and pray al­ways to a­void temp­ta­tion.
Pray to God in your families that your wives and your chil­dren may be bless­ed.
Meet to­geth­er of­ten, and for­bid no man from com­ing to you when you meet to­geth­er,
but pray for them, and do not cast them out.
When Jesus fin­ished these sayings,
he de­part­ed from them.
I, Moroni, fin­ish the rec­ord of my fa­ther, Mormon. I have on­ly a few things to write, which things my fa­ther commanded me.
Our enemies killed my fa­ther, and I a­lone re­main to write the sad tale of the de­struc­tion of my peo­ple. I don't know wheth­er they will kill me.
All my relatives have been killed in bat­tle, and I have no friends, and no­where to go.
Who­ev­er receives this rec­ord, and does­n't con­demn it be­cause of its imperfections, will know of greater things than these;
for one who judges rash­ly will be judged rash­ly a­gain; for his wages will be ac­cord­ing to his works.
The scrip­ture says, “‘Man shall not strike, nei­ther shall he judge, for judg­ment is mine, and venge­ance is mine al­so, and I will re­pay,’ says God.”
For the e­ter­nal purposes of God will roll on un­til all his promises are ful­filled.
Man­y will say, “Do this, or do that, and it does­n't mat­ter, for God will up­hold them at the last day.” But woe to them, for they are in the gall of bit­ter­ness and in the bonds of in­iq­ui­ty.
Churches will be built up that will say, “Come to me, and for your mon­ey you will be for­giv­en of your sins.”
You wick­ed and per­verse and stub­born peo­ple.
I know that you walk in the pride of your hearts, to wear­ing ver­y fi­ne cloth­ing, to en­vy­ing, strife, mal­ice, per­se­cu­tion, and all man­ner of in­iq­ui­ty.
For you love mon­ey, and your possessions, and your fi­ne cloth­ing, and adorning your churches, more than you love the poor and the needy, the sick and the afflicted.
Why do you a­dorn your­selves with what has no life and yet al­low the hun­gry, the needy, the na­ked, the sick, and the afflicted to pass by you, and not no­tice them?
Don't doubt, but be­lieve, and come to God with all your heart, and work out your own sal­va­tion with fear and trem­bling be­fore him.

Be wise dur­ing your pro­ba­tion. Strip your­selves of all im­pu­ri­ty. Don't ask so that you may spend it on your pleasures, but ask with an un­wa­ver­ing firm­ness that you will yield to no temp­ta­tion, but serve the true and liv­ing God.

Don't con­demn me or my fa­ther be­cause of our imperfections, nei­ther those who have writ­ten be­fore us. Rath­er, give thanks to God that he has revealed our imperfections to you, that you may learn to be wis­er than we have been.
I, Moroni, write some of the words of my fa­ther Mormon.
I, Mormon, speak to you.
I re­mem­ber God's word, which says you will rec­og­nize them by their works, for if their works are good then they are al­so good.
For God has said, an evil man can­not do what is good. For if he offers a gift, or prays to God, un­less he does it with re­al in­tent he gains noth­ing,
for it is not counted to him as right­eous­ness.
For if an evil man gives a gift, he does it re­luc­tant­ly, there­fore it is counted to him the same as if he had retained the gift, there­fore he is counted evil be­fore God.
Like­wise, it is counted evil to a man if he prays with­out re­al in­tent of heart. He gains noth­ing, for God receives none such.
There­fore, an evil man can­not do what is good.
A bit­ter spring can­not pour out good wa­ter; nei­ther can a good spring pour out bit­ter wa­ter.
That which is of God invites and entices to do good con­tin­u­al­ly. There­fore, eve­ry­thing which invites and entices to do good, to love God, and to serve him, is in­spired of God.
Be on guard that you don't judge what is evil to be of God, or what is good and of God to be of the dev­il.
See that you don't judge un­just­ly, for with the same judg­ment that you judge you will al­so be judged.
If a man does­n't have love he is noth­ing.

Love is pa­tient, is kind, does not en­vy, is not ar­ro­gant, is not self-seek+ing, is not ir­ri­ta­ble, keeps no rec­ord of wrongs, does not re­joice in unrighteousness but rejoices in the truth, bears all things, believes all things, hopes all things, and endures all things.
There­fore, love nev­er ends. Hold fast to love, which is the great­est of all, for all things must end,
but love endures for­ev­er, and who­ev­er possesses it at the last day, it will go well with him.
Now I, Moroni,
ex­hort you that when you read these things, you should re­mem­ber how mer­ci­ful God has been to the chil­dren of men, and pon­der it in your hearts.

Don't de­ny the gifts of God, for they are man­y, and they come from the same God. There are dif­fer­ent ways that these gifts are administered, but it is the same God who works all things in all men, and they are giv­en to prof­it men.
To one is giv­en that he may teach a mes­sage of wis­dom,
to an­oth­er teach­ing a mes­sage of knowl­edge,
to an­oth­er ver­y great faith, to an­oth­er the gifts of heal­ing,
to an­oth­er work­ing might­y miracles,
to an­oth­er proph­e­sy a­bout all things,
to an­oth­er see­ing angels and ministering spirits,
to an­oth­er all kinds of tongues,
and to an­oth­er the in­ter­pre­ta­tion of languages.
All these gifts come from God to eve­ry man in­di­vid­u­al­ly, as he wills.
Un­less you have love, faith, and hope, you can­not be saved.
If you don't have hope you must be in des­pair, and des­pair co­mes be­cause of in­iq­ui­ty.
I say to all, fare­well. I soon go to rest in God's par­a­dise.
